document.masterDocTitle: Johnwellsia, a new intertidal genus of Parastenheliidae (Copepoda, Harpacticoida) from the Taiwan Strait, China, including a review of the family and key to genera

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Johnwellsia, a new intertidal genus of Parastenheliidae (Copepoda, Harpacticoida) from the Taiwan Strait, China, including a review of the family and key to genera

mods:name.mods:affiliation: Department of Life Sciences, The Natural History Museum, Cromwell Road, London SW 7 5 BD, U. K.
College of Marine Life Science, Ocean University of China, 5 Yushan Road, Qingdao 266003, China.

heading.emphasis:
Microthalestris spinosa ( Fischer, 1860 )
comb. nov. and M. forficula ( Claus, 1863 ) comb. nov.

subSubSection.paragraph:
The original descriptions of two species that had previously been designated, validly or invalidly, as a type species ( Sars 1905: 123 ; Lang 1944: 13 ), cannot be used as the basis for their identification. Fischerâ€™s (1860) description of
Harpacticus spinosus
is grossly inadequate and renders the identification of the species indeterminable. Pending the collection of material from Madeira it must be set aside as a species inquirenda in
Microthalestris
since it does not qualify as a reference for morphological comparison with populations of
Microthalestris
(or
Parastenhelia
) spp. that have subsequently been assigned to it. The various morphs of
P. spinosa
described by Pesta (1959) , Wells & Rao (1987) and Kornev & Chertoprud (2008) as well as Apostolovâ€™s (1968) forma bulgarica are indeterminable (see Table 1 for armature formulae of P1â€“P5).

The allegedly cosmopolitan distribution of
Microthalestris spinosa
comb. nov.
is a direct result of the inadequacy of the original description and the adoption of Langâ€™s (1948) excessively broad concept of the species. The great majority of the records below are probably false or indeterminable:
Norway : Fanafjorden, south of Bergen ( Dommasnes 1969 ).
Scotland : St. Abbs ( Moore 1973 , 1974 ; Hicks 1980 ); Firth of Forth ( Shiells 1983 ); Great Cumbrae Island ( Preston & Moore 1988 , 1990 ).
England : Wembury ( Colman 1940 ) and Plymouth Sound ( Wieser 1952 ) in Devon ; Isles of Scilly ( Wells 1961 , 1970 ); Northumberland ( Moore 1973 , 1974 ).
Spain : Canary Islands , Tenerife ( Noodt 1955b ); River Ebro estuary ( Sabater 1986 ).
Montenegro : Budva ( Petkovski 1955 ).
Bulgaria : Gulf of Varna and Sozopol ( Caspers 1951 ); Sozopol ( Marinov 1974 ).
Israel : Achziv, Caesarea (= Keisarya or Qaysaria) and Palamachim ( Por 1964 ).
Mozambique : Inhaca Island ( Wells 1967 ).
Australia : Port Phillip Bay, Victoria ( Walker-Smith 2003 ).
Fiji : Moce Island ( Wells 1978 ).
Tristan da Cunha ( Wiborg 1964 ).

Similarly, Clausâ€™s (1863) description of
Thalestris forficula
is so inadequate that it is only recognizable as a
Microthalestris
by a figure of the P1. Although it should be classified as a species of doubtful identity needing further investigation ( species inquirenda ) and â€“ as a designated type species â€“ will not best serve stability and universality, this does not of itself invalidate Sarsâ€™s (1905) type fixation. The following records of
Microthalestris forficula
are considered indeterminable:
Faroe Islands : off SuÃ°uroy and between Streymoy and Eysturoy ( Stephensen 1929 ).
Northern Ireland : Ardglass, Co. Down ( Williams 1954 ).
England : Plymouth region , Devon ( Norman & Scott 1906 ; Marine Biological Association 1931 , 1957 ).
Isle of Man : Port Erin and Port St Mary ( Fraser (1936) .
France : Roscoff, Brittany ( Monard 1935a ; Jakubisiak 1936 ).
Italy : Venice Lagoon ( Grandori 1912 , 1914 ; Pesta (1920) .
U.S.A. : Gulf of Maine (north of Georges Bank) ( Bigelow 1926 ); Woods Hole ( Wilson 1932b ).
